name: Device
info:
- The components here represent a real IoT device
  (e.g. Arduino Uno) or a simulated IoT device.

- We organise the components here according to the 
  Arduino programming convention

- All Arduino programs start execution at the `setup()` 
  function. The `setup()` function is called once
  to perform any device or sensor initialisation.

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

- The `loop()` function is called repeatedly
  to allow the Arduino program to perform any required
  tasks.  A typical `loop()` function will:

0. Read data from a sensor.
1. Process the data read. Possibly encode to save space.
2. Transmit the data e.g. over Sigfox. 
3. Delay a few seconds before restarting the loop

-  The Sigfox shield will not allow two transmissions within 10 seconds.
   So it's a good practice to insert a delay of 10 seconds at 
   the end of the `loop()` function.

name: Rule Engine
info:
- The **Rule Engine** is the component in the
  Cloud IoT platform (e.g. AWS IoT, Azure IoT)
  that executes rules to process any sensor
  data received.

- Most Cloud IoT platforms support `if ... then ... else ... `
  kind of rules. A rule could trigger an **alert** 
  (e.g. email, SMS alerts),
  update a **database** (for rendering dashboards)
  or execute an **external service** (e.g. predict
  sensor values based on machine learning)

- In this example the rules update the **Physical
  and Logical Device States** to record the
  variables needed for business logic e.g.
  "Is the light on?" "What time did the light turn off?"

name: Alerts
info:
- **Alerts** are notifications to a person or to
  another system, triggered by rules in the **Rule Engine.**

- In **AWS IoT** we will learn to send alerts for
  **email, SMS and automated voice call.**

name: Sensor Data Store
info:
- Preferably a Time Series Database like InfluxDB
- MySQL works fine for low data volume

name: Deep IoT
info:
- **Deep IoT** refers to devices that tend
  to do more processing locally, so the require
  more network bandwidth, more power

- **Amazon Echo / Alexa** is a good example.
  It performs some audio processing locally
  and it uses WiFi to send/receive data.
  It's not meant to run on battery power.

- This has been the traditional model for
  IoT: smart, localised devices that have
  constraints on location, power, network
  connectivity.

- **Deep IoT** has also been noted to have a
  higher Total Cost of Ownership because
  more things can go wrong locally.  Think
  about a Raspberry Pi and the possibility
  that its SD card could be corrupted beyond repair.
  Compare that with an Arduino Uno that has
  no filesystem.

- In this course we'll focus on a more challenging
  and impactful class of IoT devices called
  **Wide IoT** devices that have much fewer
  constraints on location, power and 
  network connectivity

name: Wide IoT
info:
- In this course we'll focus on a more challenging
  and impactful class of IoT devices called
  **Wide IoT** devices that have much fewer
  constraints on location, power and 
  network connectivity

- **Wide IoT** devices are designed for
  widespread deployment. They use 
  **Low Power Wide Area Networks (LPWAN)** like 
  **Sigfox, LoRa, NB-IoT**

- They are designed to run on battery power,
  up to months and years of battery life.
  The networks are available city-wide, e.g.
  most parts of Singapore are already covered
  by Sigfox.  So the devices will work anywhere
  without a power outlet.

- The **Arduino Uno with UnaShield Sigfox Shield**
  makes a good device for **Wide IoT** because
  it runs on battery power and can transmit
  sensor data from most areas in Singapore.

- **Wide IoT** devices like the 
  **Arduino Uno with UnaShield** also tend
  to be lower in cost than **Deep IoT** devices.

- The Total Cost of Ownership of these devices
  tend to be lower because they have fewer
  components that may cause problems

name: Physical Device State
info:
-- The **Physical Device State** contains the 
   sensor values before executing any rules
   in the Rule Engine.
   
-- In **AWS IoT** the **Physical Device State** is
   also known as the **Device Shadow,** because it
   remembers (shadows) the last known state of the device
   (e.g. Arduino Uno) and its sensors (e.g. Light Sensor).
   
-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on (`light_detected = true / false`). 
   `light_detected` is stored in the **Logical Device State.**
   
-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on.
   
-- In this simulation, the **Physical Device State**
   is stored in a variable named `last_physical_device_state`
   in the Node-RED flow context.

name: Logical Device State
info:
-- The **Logical Device State** contains the 
   sensor values before executing any rules
   in the Rule Engine.
   
-- The rules in the Rule Engine may make use of the
   **Physical Device State** to derive the
   **Logical Device State,** which is more
   business-oriented

-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on (`light_detected = true / false`). 
   `light_detected` is stored in the **Logical Device State.**

-- The second set of rules below will read the
   `light_detected` status from the **Logical Device State**
   and compute `light_off_timestamp`, `light_off_duration`,
   which will be stored in the **Logical Device State**
   
-- In this simulation, the **Logical Device State**
   is stored in a variable named `last_logical_device_state`
   in the Node-RED flow context.
